DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Nikkei Up
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchage reversed its early downswing and edged up Wednesday, while the dollar firmed against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 144.23 yen, up 0.43 yen from Tuesday's close of 143.80 yen. It started trading at 143.92 yen and ranged between 143.90 yen and 144.25 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues regained 72.90 points, or 0.19 percent, ending the day at 38,512.00. It lost 147.08 points Tuesday on rumors the Bank of Japan might raise the nation's discount rate by the weekend. Market players, however, avoided making major moves amid uncertainties over the discount-rate increase, said Tomoyuki Morimoto, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. ``Many market players were reluctant to make major moves amid uncertainty over the discount rate hike,'' he said. ``Few people will be inclined to buy further until they find out what exactly will happen to the rate.'' Higher interest rates discourage stock investment. News reports speculated the Bank of Japan might raise its key lending rate to commercial banks by 0.5 percentage point to 4.25 percent, but both the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan denied the hike would happen any time soon. Kyodo News Service reported Wednesday the central bank will begin negotiations with the government in an attempt to raise the discount rate soon, citing sources from within the Bank of Japan. In currency dealings, trading was quiet in the absence of fresh market-affecting news ahead of the Christmas holiday, traders said. ``Although the market was hectic yesterday due to the rumor about the discount rate, it no longer has any impact here. The market already expects there will be a hike sometime early next year,'' said a trader with Mitsubishi Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity.
